Played both these games on PS5 when they came out individually and was delighted to hear they were coming to PC. Stories and characters are great, visuals are awesome and they are just pure fun to play (and replay). Just waiting for the day when Sony sort out Uncharted 1-3 (and the PS Vita one) into a PC pack - I think you'll find a lot of people would lap that up too.

Wish Naughty Dog would port the other Uncharted games, as well. Seeing how well this was done makes me want to see the other games remade in all their goodness.

The game itself is great. I only had one issue with loading shaders and two crashes that were fixed with a driver update. Your mileage may vary.

Here, have some Indiana Jones. Take some of this Tomb Raider too. What do you get? Tomb Jones. But what we have here are the adventures of some people with upper body strength so incredible, it is only surpassed by their ability to cheat death about three dozen times a day.

If you want a game that tells you all these emergent little stories through interaction, this is not it. In the familiar Naughty Dog fashion, this is a movie that you play through. It's a wild ride with high emphasis on production values, motion capture and voice acting. There is one path forward and even that practically plays itself, until you reach an action scene, and you get to do at least something. The good thing is that the action is fun enough to keep you going and I like the contrast between the game basically running on autopilot and the sometimes even, gasp, challenging combat. Drake's superhuman ability to throw himself up a mountain doesn't mean he can eat bullets forever, albeit he can eat bullets a lot, and I liked coming up with different ways of clearing those arenas. Enemies can be deadly and they will come after you if you as much as take cover for too long.

I don't particularly like this sort of entirely linear and expendable game design, but I can't say I'm impervious to Uncharted 4's entertainment value, because it kept me entertained enough.

I've completed Uncharted 4 now three times. An ambitious game and a fitting sendoff for Nate and the crew, I think it falls short of the best in the series, and even ties or comes in below U3 for me personally. Graphically, it is the best in the series and is downright gorgeous. The grappling hook feels like a natural extension of Nathan, and I can't believe it's taken 4 games for us to get this: it's that good. Gunplay and climbing also feel leagues above U3 and U2, so why the inevitable BUT? Story and characters both take a mistep here. 

Nadine-Let's start with the obvious one. Much complaint was made about Nadine when U4 first launched in 2016. While IMO much of it was overblown, there are some valid criticisms. The fact that she is able to completely kick Nate's ass not once, but twice along with his brother at the same time is laughable. There are ways to write bad-ass female characters, but making one who is able to not just hold her own but pulverize two grown men at the same time is not it. 

Rafe-Personally, I think Rafe is the best villain of the series. While that may not be saying much, and in the grand scheme of things he is just another rich goon with another private militia behind him, he at least has some depth to him given his past history with the Drake brothers. I think a lot is left on the table with him in this regard, especially given his drive to find Libertalia and Avery's treasure mirroring Nate's in a darker fashion. I wish ND explored this dichotomy more, and had more story moments showing how Nate and Rafe aren't so different at the end of the day, and the lengths at which these two men are willing to go to achieve their ends. Bonus points for the final fight with him, which is climactic and the best "final boss" fight in the franchise. 

Sam-Where do I start with Sam? He is an extremely well written character, and feels like a natural extension playing off of Nathan once you get over the sudden whiplash of his introduction. I theorize Amy Hennig departed Naughty Dog because of Sam and the way he is written into the story. Nowhere in the past 3 games did we ever get to know this long-lost brother nor was he ever mentioned, and it feels very unnatural for him to show up and drive the main plot of the series. 

Elena-I'll keep this one brief. Elena's character is fine overall, but I don't buy Nathan lying to her and setting out for adventure with Sam. After getting to know her for over 3 games, and all of the adventures these two have been on together, it makes no sense for Nathan to concoct a lie to her when I feel she would have been ok with him going and likely even tagging along. Negative points for the length "apology" section of the story where the action grounds to a halt just over midway through, and we are forced to solve elevator and car puzzles with her. 

Lost Legacy-This is a fine DLC, and it's great to see Chloe back in action after her distinct absence from U3. Unfortunately, Neil Druckmann heard gamers loud and clear and decided to shoehorn everyone's favorite character, Nadine, back into the story. While she is slightly more tolerable here, I would've much rather her be partnered up with Sam, or even Charlie Cutter from 3 who is also noticeably absent from this game.

The story is heartfelt, really focusing on the characters, with messaging that will hit home for many, and really shines through the characters and their interactions with one another, particularly with the witty dialogue and swagger of the main character. It is a beautiful story focusing on Nathan Drake and those who have molded him over the previous three games, and probably one of the best I've experienced in a game. The spin-off game included in this bundle continues in much the same way as a thief's end, with a different main character, but plays much the same. The story is well-made and entertaining, and Lost Legacy experiments with a more open-world design which pays off well, making the gameplay and exploration more interesting in a good way. The exploration of a part of the world not seen at all in previous outings works well, and both games are a must play. 10/10.

As a diehard fan of narrative-driven games, I have to say that despite being a masterpiece of industrial game production with many merits, the obviously altered happy ending made me write it off completely. (Spoiler alert)
1. The final act suffers from a noticeable drop in quality, with clear signs of rushing. While the mid-section is packed with surprises, the climaxâ€”which should have been the highlightâ€”feels surprisingly lackluster.  
2. The gameâ€™s underlying theme mirrors a pirate utopia saga, where the leaderâ€™s greed-driven betrayals unfold in parallel with the growing ideological rift between the Drake brothers.  
3. The story heavily emphasizes the complicated history between the brothers: Nathanâ€™s reluctant abandonment, Samâ€™s deception, his distrust toward Sully, his pride, and his simmering jealousy toward his brother. All of this sets a solid foundation for Samâ€™s descent into darkness. In contrast, Rafe feels underdeveloped, even overshadowed by the mercenary leader in terms of presence.  
4. What really convinced me that the ending was altered is that scene at the Libertalia blacksmith ruins: when Nathan examines an artifact, Sam suddenly attacks him with a broken sword(ofcu's jokingly). Nathan is startled, then falls into an unsettling silence.  

Sam was the one who introduced Nathan to this lifeâ€”even the â€œDrakeâ€ alias was his idea. But after spending 15 years in prison following a failed escape, he watches as Nathan achieves three legendary archaeological discoveries, getting closer to fulfilling their motherâ€™s legacy. From his perspective, Nathanâ€”who settled into a quiet life after retirementâ€”is a traitor. Sam was left behind, and the person who eventually bailed him out wasnâ€™t his own brother, but someone he didnâ€™t even trust.  
So from the very beginning, Sam wasnâ€™t fully honest with Nathan. He fabricated the story about a drug lord, waited a long time after getting out before contacting Nathan, and more. Throughout their journey, the two donâ€™t grow closerâ€”instead, the gap between them widens. Deceptions, bullets, falling off cliffsâ€¦ The long conversation at the Libertalia tavern lays their conflicting values bare. After that, the underlying theme of pirates turning on each other surfaces unmistakably. At this point, Samâ€™s turn to darkness feels inevitable.  

The most fitting ending would have been Samâ€™s betrayal, culminating in a final sword fight between the brothers, with Sam meeting his end aboard the pirate ship.  
I understand that as the series finale, a happy ending is what many hoped for. But forcing a cheerful resolution while ignoring or overwriting the established narrative buildup is a disservice to the art of storytelling.

TL:DR - I can't give it a full-throated recommendation because of what Uncharted 4 is bundled with here. Because in almost every way U4 is great, Lost Legacy is bad - except the usual gameplay loop, which is largely identical between the two. So - yes, and no.

Spoilers ahead.

I'm new to the series, and only started with these 2. And 4 left me feeling like, hell yes - can I have more of this! It's Adventure with a capital A and is very addictive in the way it draws you in and always keeps wondering what happens next, while exploring and gawking at the gorgeous world. Story is fun, characters well written, dialogue is snappy. Bad-guys aren't exactly textbook "bad", since, what you are doing yourself and your goal there is essentially the same as mercs' - treasure, even though for different underlying reasons. I was surprised how long it is, for a more linear game - and that is to its benefit - it dots all the i's by the end. 

I didn't mind Nadine in U4 at all. Looking at how the action goes in Uncharted, it is all quite over-the-top, wall-crushing, slide-jumping, 1-man-army craziness. And her being sort of the main "villain" - you'd expect her to be tough as nails, because that's just how it goes - you don't get to take out the main baddie in one shot. With all that, you get your suspension of disbelief at a reasonable level - you "just go with it" fairly easily. U4 left me thoroughly impressed overall - it is definitely the crown of this bundle.

Unfortunately instead of a jewel, there's a turd on top of that crown - and that is Lost Legacy.

It still sort of remains on-the-rails linear adventure, but much more open this time. And those more open-world'ish maps (there's really just the one) is where you feel how it detracts from the razor-sharp focus and urgency the previous game is great at.

What if Tomb Raider had a lame side-kick ? (yes, ok ... Jonah, you're right). It would be this. It has an obnoxious, foul-tempered, abrasive bitch of a side-kick, who is somehow worse than she was as villain in U4 ! I sort of expected some degree of woke nonsense from NaughtyDog at some point - so I wasn't exactly surprised by this. 

It's the usual tired old crap of elevating a girl, by putting a guy down - and yes Sam gets put down all the time, being written as this mewling, pathetic tool. There is literally a scene where he joins Chloe in a jeep and gets immediately yelled at by Strong Diverse Woman to go take the back-seat. Which he complies with immediately, like a limp little soy-noodle. This unbelievable, dysfunctional relations-dynamic totally drowns out the few good things about this game, which would've been actually half-decent otherwise.

Suspension of disbelief ? I'd sooner want to believe Chloe powersliding down a slope, while no-scoping 10 mercs in the span of 5 seconds, than her putting up with that hissing pot of vitriol sitting next to her, and not ejecting her out of her seat at the next tall cliff.

Chloe is OK, but nothing more than that. She's voiced by Claudia Black, which is always an auditory treat - but she's given the most cringy, sinfully boring script, which can't keep your attention for 10 seconds, because how rottedly mundane it is. Every time there's banter between the 2 characters - my mind would wander, looking for something more engaging - like counting my teeth using my tongue.

If I could rate U4 separately, I'd recommend it wholeheartedly. But in this "collection", the difference between the 2 games is just vast. I'd never pay for Legacy, and looking at the stuff ND have released lately - I'd never give them my money again. 

But I'm glad I got U4 from it at least.

TL:DR - I can't give it a full-throated recommendation because of what Uncharted 4 is bundled with here. Because in almost every way U4 is great, Lost Legacy is bad - except the usual gameplay loop, which is largely identical between the two. So - yes, and no.

Spoilers ahead.

I'm new to the series, and only started with these 2. And 4 left me feeling like, hell yes - can I have more of this! It's Adventure with a capital A and is very addictive in the way it draws you in and always keeps wondering what happens next, while exploring and gawking at the gorgeous world. Story is fun, characters well written, dialogue is snappy. Bad-guys aren't exactly textbook "bad", since, what you are doing yourself and your goal there is essentially the same as mercs' - treasure, even though for different underlying reasons. I was surprised how long it is, for a more linear game - and that is to its benefit - it dots all the i's by the end. 

I didn't mind Nadine in U4 at all. Looking at how the action goes in Uncharted, it is all quite over-the-top, wall-crushing, slide-jumping, 1-man-army craziness. And her being sort of the main "villain" - you'd expect her to be tough as nails, because that's just how it goes - you don't get to take out the main baddie in one shot. With all that, you get your suspension of disbelief at a reasonable level - you "just go with it" fairly easily. U4 left me thoroughly impressed overall - it is definitely the crown of this bundle.

Unfortunately instead of a jewel, there's a turd on top of that crown - and that is Lost Legacy.

It still sort of remains on-the-rails linear adventure, but much more open this time. And those more open-world'ish maps (there's really just the one) is where you feel how it detracts from the razor-sharp focus and urgency the previous game is great at.

What if Tomb Raider had a lame side-kick ? (yes, ok ... Jonah, you're right). It would be this. It has an obnoxious, foul-tempered, abrasive bitch of a side-kick, who is somehow worse than she was as villain in U4 ! I sort of expected some degree of woke nonsense from NaughtyDog at some point - so I wasn't exactly surprised by this. 

It's the usual tired old crap of elevating a girl, by putting a guy down - and yes Sam gets put down all the time, being written as this mewling, pathetic tool. There is literally a scene where he joins Chloe in a jeep and gets immediately yelled at by Strong Diverse Woman to go take the back-seat. Which he complies with immediately, like a limp little soy-noodle. This unbelievable, dysfunctional relations-dynamic totally drowns out the few good things about this game, which would've been actually half-decent otherwise.

Suspension of disbelief ? I'd sooner want to believe Chloe powersliding down a slope, while no-scoping 10 mercs in the span of 5 seconds, than her putting up with that hissing pot of vitriol sitting next to her, and not ejecting her out of her seat at the next tall cliff.

Chloe is OK, but nothing more than that. She's voiced by Claudia Black, which is always an auditory treat - but she's given the most cringy, sinfully boring script, which can't keep your attention for 10 seconds, because how rottedly mundane it is. Every time there's banter between the 2 characters - my mind would wander, looking for something more engaging - like counting my teeth using my tongue.

If I could rate U4 separately, I'd recommend it wholeheartedly. But in this "collection", the difference between the 2 games is just vast. I'd never pay for Legacy, and looking at the stuff ND have released lately - I'd never give them my money again. 

But I'm glad I got U4 from it at least.
